title: Clapham Wood Walking Route

images.title: Slbs [CC BY-SA 2.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Clearing in Clapham Wood. A public footpath can be seen running to the left of the fence. The clearing is large yet seems not to be marked on the OS 50,000 and 25,000 scale maps. It is used as pasture, mostly sheep, some cattle.

images.title: Slbs [CC BY-SA 2.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Grub Ride, Clapham Wood. A public footpath crosses Grub Ride at this point; it runs on the left between the signpost and the nearest young oak tree. The oaks were planted in memory of Bert Searle, a woodman well-known locally. Taken in June. Bert Searle's memorial plaque is now almost hidden by undergrowth.

images.title: Simon Carey / Clapham Wood
images.caption: The woods viewed from a footpath that links Longfurlong with another running along the hedge in the centre and looking towards the edge of the woods perched on top of the hill.

images.title: Slbs / Junction of tracks in Clapham Wood
images.caption: Junction of tracks in the woods. The track branching off to the left is a public footpath leading to Clapham Farm; the track straight ahead is Grub Ride.

images.title: Little Thatch, The Street by Simon Carey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Little Thatch, The Street. A view of the picturesque thatched cottages in the village of Clapham.

images.title: Dave Spicer / St Mary the Virgin
images.caption: St Mary the Virgin. The church dates from the 12th century and is located on the edge of the woods.

images.title: Peter Holmes / The World's End, Patching
images.caption: The World's End, Patching. You could pop into the neighbouring village for a stroll and a pint after your exercise.

images.title: Field, Clapham Wood by Simon Carey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Field, Clapham Wood

description: These mysterious woods are located in the Arun District of West Sussex, next to the village of Clapham. The woods are most well known for paranormal activity including several UFO sightings. They also have some nice public footpaths to follow through the woods. The woods are surrounded by some lovely Sussex countryside and have bluebells growing in the spring. There's parking available at the south western corner of the woods.
